column4: So uname -a shows the kernel I'm using and /boot shows one with a higher version, and I'm currently uninstalling the one I'm running. Have a screwed up?
why and how are you uninstalling the kernel?
The boot partition was full of old ones...but I may have mis-calculated which I can remove. Removing it with apt-get.
you didn't install a new one before?
Well, it's in /boot, so I suppose it's installed.
i wouldn't count on that, check using dpkg
Dpkg shows ii next to the version higher than the one I'm removing.
Meaning it's installed, yes?
should be good then, just run update-grub before you reboot
that should have been run automatically already, right?
Is there a way to tell if the system is awaiting a reboot from me?
it can't hurt to do it again
do you have a desktop
Naw, it's a server, and I a poor admin, but I notice now that the MOTD wants a reboot.
is it a server you can physically touch?
Nope, but I can find somebody that can....with some effort.
then you'll want to make sure grub is good before rebooting :)
Hahaha, eff, not my finest hour...but at least /boot will have some space, I suppose. Thanks for the help.
no problem. i've been managing servers for about a decade now
Once it comes back up from the reboot, am I safe deleting all the other old kernel bits sitting around in /boot?
apt-get should remove all those
Excellent. I'll put it to work. Thanks again.
